subject: Re: [junit] Testing on AWT thread

messageBody:
Hi Alex,

Thank you for your suggestions, I looked into the FEST framework and I
actually have started to use it. However, when I tried to use it I would
still get the same problem that I started this thread with.

From what I can tell by looking at the FEST source is that FEST still
queries the table from whichever thread it is being called from. This again
brings me back to my problem: How do I query the table that gets modified on
the EDT thread from a junit thread.

I ultimately ended up using SwingUtilities.invokeAndWait using a final int
array that stores the number of rows in the table. I then use an assert
after the invoteAndWait on this final int array to make sure the number of
rows is correct.

One other thing, so happens when I finally got around to your suggestion and
looked at FEST, you had taken out the GuiTask class! I finally figured it
out and noticed too that you are adding a whole lot of queries that get run
in the EDT thread. So far I really like what I see with FEST and will
continue to use it.

Thanks for the suggestions and keep up the good work!
Aaron


Alex Ruiz wrote:
>
> Hi Aaron,
>
> My suggestion is either:
>
> 1. Use FEST ( http://fest.easytesting.org/swing ) to
> test your GUIs. FEST is a library provides a compact,
> intuitive and easy-to-use API that makes GUI testing
> easy (disclaimer: I'm the creator of FEST.)
>
> 2. If you decide not to use FEST, you can still use
> FEST's GuiTask to solve your problem. Since FEST is
> open source and under the Apache 2.0 license, you can
> copy the source of GuiTask. Please note that GuiTask
> uses invokeAndWait instead of invokeLater. IMHO, most
> of the time in your test you need to wait for an
> action to be executed in the EDT before you can
> continue the execution of your test. You can find the
> code for GuiTask at
> http://code.google.com/p/fest/source/browse/trunk/fest/fest-swing/src/main/java/org/fest/swing/core/GuiTask.java
>
> Cheers,
> -Alex
>
>
> --- hybrid180 <aaron@...> wrote:

>> Hi,
>>
>> I am actually relatively new to Junit testing and I
>> have a quick question
>> about running tests on two different threads. I am
>> trying to verify that
>> something is done on the swing thread with a junit
>> test. For example the
>> following:
>>
>> SwingUtilities.invokeLater(new Runnable(){
>> public void run() {
>> assertEquals(2, tableModel.getRowCount());
>> };
>>
>> });
>>
>> When this test actually fails I've noticed an
>> AssertionError exception is
>> thrown on the Swing thread but the test overall
>> still passes.
>>
>> My question is this: is there a way to make the test
>> not pass when this
>> assert fails? Or at least throw the AssertionError
>> on the Junit thread
>> instead of the Swing thread?
>>
>> Thanks for any help,
>> Aaron
